hand.section:
The copie of my l
re
written to yo
r
L.
e 28 of June 1591 from Leewarden.

page.lettertext:
fol.162r
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised that two
daies after the fort of
Delfzile
was yeelded up, w
ch
was
don the 22
th
of this moneth, as then I writ unto yo
r
L.
by 2 several letters, our armie marched towards
Opslack,
w
ch
is a sconce that
e ennemy held upon a
point of land by
Groeninghen
diepe, w
th
in 2 englishe
miles from
Northoorn,
where
S
r
John Norreis
receaved his
great overthrow. It was three daies marche from
Delfzile, and a place of good strength, having in it a
garrison of 150 souldiers, and 5 great peeces of
artillerie. First it was besieged w
th
2000 men, and
for half a daie battered w
th
5 cannons, wheruppon being
summoned, and not yeelding,
e rest of the armie was
caused to approache, w
ch
brought them p
nt
lie to parle.
But better conditions, then to depart w
th
white rode in
their hande would not bee graunted. There were found
3 english souldiers in
e ennemies service, w
ch
S
r
Francis
Vere
staied, and caused to bee hanged in
e englishe quarter.
After
e taking of this fort, it was resolved that
Emmentel
should bee summoned, w
ch
is a place of like force as
e form
r
and, as wee are
swaded, will p
nt
lie give over, for feare of
enforcement to a hard composition. Moreover, for that
all
e fortes of the ennemy in
e Province of Groningen,
w
ch
were not so fewe as 20 in nomber, are either taken
by us, or forsaken by them selves. wherby the towne of
Groeninghen is greatlie distressed, and excluded from all
traffique, and meanes to come by vittailes, unles it bee
by land by the meanes of
Coeveorden,
w
ch
is a very strong
fort of the Ennemy situate in that part of
Overissel,
w
ch
is called
Drent
,
southwest from Groninghen, 7 dutch miles
fol.162v
for the winning of that place it is thought expedient, that
Steenwick a great garrison towne upon
e northwest
frontiers of Overissel should bee first taken in, as well for
the easier expugnation of Coeveorden, as for sondry other
opportunities, it being a place, that doth greatly dammefie
all their countrey therabout. All this was thus concluded
yesterdaie, and
e campe as this daie removeth toward
Emmentel
. But
e
Councel of State
is going towards
Steenwick, both to m ake provision for some want
of
e
armie, and to accommodate them selves of some convenient
place of residence neere unto
e towne. For w
ch
purpose
wee are alredy in o
r
waie so farre as Leewarden, from
whence I write your L. this l
re
. The
Duke of
Parma
,
as wee are informed, wanting meanes of cariage, vittailes,
and many other necessaries, and also of forces sufficient
to encounter w
th
ours, is gon toward
Ruremonde
a strong
towne upon the
Mose
in
Guelderland,
w
th
what intention
wee knowe not assuredlie, but as many men report to go
for
france.
And if it bee trew, in my conceat of these
actions, all
e souldiers of this armie are so verie well
disposed, and
e countrey so willing to fournish what is
needfull, as her
Ma
ty
shall finde, that
e forces of these
countreis did never hethertoo
fourme a better sommers service.
From Leewarden. June 28 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
